summary: syncytial virus (RSV) is the most important cause of viral pneumonia in children worldwide. a maternal vaccine may protect both the mother and infant from RSV illness. maternal immunization against influenza, tetanus, and pertusiss has been shown to be safe, immunogenic, and efficacious in preventing disease in infants. influenza vaccination during pregnancy is associated with decreased maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. an RSV illness episode was defined as the presence of any symptoms occurring for a minimum of one day with a mid-nasal swab obtained and RSV detected on PCR assay. clinical and sociodemographic data were collected at enrollment and weekly visits. birthweight was included in the analysis if obtained within the first 72 hours after birth. 3693 pregnant women were enrolled and followed from April 2011 to May 2014. 944 nasal swabs were collected during 3554 person-years of follow-up while pregnant or postpartum. a respiratory virus detected in 556 (59%) of these swabs. in number of other children in the household (P = 0.80), use of an open indoor cookstove (P = 0.09) or presence of household members who smoked (P = 0.73) comparison of sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of women with and without RSV infection. seven (50%) mothers sought care at local health care facilities. of these, two visited a medicine shop and five saw a practitioner. no mothers with RSV infection died. onavirus (n = 1;
